I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  support  trade  facilitation 
implementation in the developing member countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) through research and development, capacity building, and collaboration with the United 
Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (ESCAP) for the conduct of 
the Asia-Pacific Trade Facilitation Forum (APTFF).1 This will synergize the efforts of ADB’s 
regional departments and the Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD) to improve and 
facilitate cross-border trade. 
 
2.  The Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department’s annual work plan for 
2020 identifies the TA as a priority project. It will complement (i) trade facilitation initiatives in 
other  ADB  departments  and  in  subregional  programs  such  as  the  Central  Asia  Regional 
Economic  Cooperation  (CAREC),  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS),  and  South  Asia 
Subregional  Economic  Cooperation  (SASEC);2 and  (ii)  the  memorandum  of  understanding 
between ADB and ESCAP, which identifies trade facilitation as a priority area of collaboration.3 
The Operational Plan for Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2016–2020 also prioritizes 
stronger connectivity between economies through trade facilitation.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  It  is  well  documented  that  trade  facilitation  measures  help  raise  efficiency  and 
transparency  in  cross-border  trade,  lowering  trade  costs  and  boosting  trade  flows.  Full 
implementation  of  the  World  Trade  Organization  (WTO)  Trade  Facilitation  Agreement  can 
reduce trade costs by 9% on average, or up to 16% if digital trade facilitation measures are 
implemented. 5  The  largest  gains  are  expected  for  developing  economies  lagging  in 
implementation  of  digital  trade  facilitation.  Paperless  trade  measures  can  facilitate 
mainstreaming of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) into international value chains, 
which promotes more inclusive employment and development. Pursuit of these measures aligns 
well with ADB’s Strategy 2030, in addition to improving trade competitiveness of countries and 
bringing them closer to the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals.6 
 
 
1 ADB has supported the APTFF since 2009, which has enabled the participation of government officials and 
resource persons from the DMCs. Organizers have held nine forums so far, the last one in 2019 in New Delhi, 
India. Asia Regional Integration Center. Asia-Pacific Trade Facilitation Forum 2019: Digital and Sustainable Trade 
Facilitation for Regional Prosperity.  
2 ADB. 2019. CAREC Integrated Trade Agenda 2030 and Rolling Strategic Action Plan, 2018–2020. Manila; ADB. 
2016. South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation Operational Plan, 2016–2025; and ADB. 2018. The Ha Noi 
Action Plan, 2018–2022. Manila. 
3 The existing memorandum will expire on 31 December 2020. Discussions for updating it are ongoing, and trade 
facilitation has been identified as a priority area of cooperation. 
4 ADB. 2016. Operational Plan for Regional Cooperation and Integration. (2016-2020: Promoting Connectivity, 
Competitiveness, Regional Public Goods, and Collective Action for Asia and the Pacific). Manila. The TA first 
appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 26 November 2020. 
5 ADB and ESCAP. 2019. Asia-Pacific Trade Facilitation Report 2019: Bridging Trade Finance Gaps Through      
   Technology. Manila.  
6 Advancement of trade facilitation measures falls under operational priority 7 (fostering regional cooperation and 
integration) of ADB’s Strategy 2030. The implementation of these measures is expected to improve services at 
related government offices, which aligns with operational priority 6 (strengthening governance and institutional 
capacity). ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the 
Pacific. Manila.

2 
4.  Paperless  trade  measures  also  enhance  access  to  finance—a  critical  constraint  in 
trade―through innovative financial technologies for SMEs with limited access to formal banking 
systems.7 Digital  financial  technologies,  or  fintech,  give  rise  to  an  array  of  applications  in 
financial services, such as payment, financing, asset management, and financial advice. These 
technologies help address the main challenges in trade finance provision, including process 
inefficiency,  regulatory  compliance,  and  information  asymmetry,  thus  lowering  the  costly 
customer due diligence requirements for banks. 
 
5.  Economies in Asia and the Pacific are steadily implementing trade facilitation measures, 
although  much  remains  to  be  done. Overall  trade  facilitation  implementation  in the  region 
increased from 49% in 2017 to 59% in 2019.8 But subregional implementation rates vary, with 
higher rates in Australia and New Zealand (93%) and East Asia high (79%), but lower rates in 
Central Asia (66%), South Asia (55%), and the Pacific (36%). Moreover, measures for cross-
border paperless trade and inclusive trade are lagging. Cross-border paperless trade measures 
are implemented only 40% on average and often on a pilot basis. Low implementation rates are 
also observed for trade facilitation for agriculture (50%), SMEs (36%), and female-owned firms 
(23%). Measures for trade finance facilitation are found to be rarely implemented. 
   
6.  The coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic has had a major impact on international 
trade, forecast to fall 9.2% in 2020, and has exposed vulnerabilities in the world trading system.9 
Lockdowns and transport restrictions have disrupted supply chains and hampered cross-border 
trade of essential food and medical supplies as well as key income-generating products. For 
customs and logistics, the prevalence of manual submissions, paper-based filings, physical 
interface points, and lack of coordination mechanisms constrains trade activity. The pandemic 
has also revealed (i) the lack of emergency protocols in trade; (ii) a need for a holistic approach 
in transparency, information sharing, transportation, logistics, and transit facilitation; and (iii) the 
need to expedite digital trade reforms. 
 
7.  A  digital  transformation  in  trade  and  trade  facilitation  will  likely  accelerate  in  the 
aftermath of the pandemic. Trade facilitation is already one of the main strategic and operational 
priorities in ADB’s subregional programs, including CAREC, GMS, and SASEC (footnote 2). 
These  priorities  can  be  further  strengthened  when  post-COVID-19  policy  lessons  and 
implications are linked up with existing or renewed agendas and potentially shared among the 
subregional programs. 
 
8.  The  transition  to  the  “new  normal”  after  the  COVID-19  pandemic  will  require  a 
knowledge  base  for  forward-looking  trade  facilitation  policy  making  as  well  as  enhanced 
capacity building for stakeholders, including customs and trade officials. DMCs will benefit from 
building  more  resilient  supply  chains  with  enhanced  information  sharing,  adequate  digital 
infrastructure, and regulatory systems to implement digital trade facilitation. It is also important 
to  promote  greater  access  to  trade  finance  for  SMEs  disproportionately  impacted  by  the 
 
7 The rejection rate of bank-intermediated trade finance applications in 2019 for SMEs was 45%, compared to 39% 
for large companies and 17% for multinational corporations. ADB. 2019. 2019 Trade Finance Gaps, Growth, and 
Jobs Survey. ADB Briefs. No. 113. Manila. 
8 ESCAP. 2019. Digital and Sustainable Trade Facilitation Implementation in Asia and the Pacific 2019.. Bangkok. 
The survey covers four areas: (i) general trade facilitation; (ii) digital trade facilitation; (iii) sustainable trade 
facilitation; and (iv) trade finance where 100% implementation implies full compliance with commonly accepted 
international standards. 
9 WTO. 2020. Trade shows signs of rebound from COVID-19, recovery still uncertain. News release. 6 October.

3 
pandemic’s economic fallout. Countries should focus on building capacity for better coordination 
and cooperation among all stakeholders. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: opportunities for trade and trade facilitation 
agenda  advanced  (footnote  4),10 and  economic  opportunities  for  SMEs,  especially  those 
managed  by  women  entrepreneurs,  increased.11 The  TA  will  have  the  following  outcome: 
design and implementation of DMC trade facilitation measures, especially in paperless trade, 
improved.12 The outcome will be measured in terms of trade facilitation policies that DMCs will 
adopt. These measures will focus on (i) cross-border paperless trade as part of forward-looking 
policies and (ii) SMEs to help them and women entrepreneurs benefit from the improved trade 
environment. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output  1:  Best  practices  and  benefits  of  trade  facilitation  and  trade  finance 
advocated and disseminated. The TA will support the conduct of the APTFF in 2021 and 2023 
to  continue  to  provide  venues  for  policy  dialogues  that  enable  the  sharing  of  knowledge, 
experiences, and lessons among public and private stakeholders, including industry or trade 
associations  that  represent  SMEs  and/or  large  businesses.13 Various  topics  that  will  be 
discussed at the APTFFs include (i) opportunities for the future trade facilitation agenda, such 
as  cross-border  paperless  trade  and  innovative  applications  of  emerging  technologies  for 
sustainable progress of the region; and (ii) challenges ahead in materializing such opportunities. 
To better understand the critical role of access to finance in inclusive and sustainable trade, a 
session on trade finance will be included in the agenda for at least one APTFF in consultation 
with ADB’s Trade and Supply Chain Finance Program, which is part of the PSOD. 
 
10.  Output 2: Capacities of trade agencies to initiate digital trade and trade facilitation 
measures enhanced. The TA will collaborate with ADB’s regional departments and relevant 
technical groups to organize and determine capacity building activities for key government 
officials during the APTFFs. In addition, the TA will also organize and support two subregional 
meetings  (i)  to  bridge  knowledge  gaps  based  on  the  feedback  from  the  capacity  building 
participants during the APTFFs; (ii) to cater to trade and trade facilitation issues and challenges 
specific  to  the  subregions;  and  (iii)  to  explore  synergies  with  ADB-supported  subregional 
initiatives such as CAREC, GMS, and SASEC. In designing the capacity building events, the TA 
will likewise consult with regional departments and collaborate with the subregional programs; 
think tanks; and international organizations like ESCAP, the WTO, and the World Customs 
Organization to better align with operational goals and subregional strategies. 
 
10 ADB. 2019. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 7: Fostering Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2019–
2024. Manila; and ADB. 2016. Operational Plan for Regional Cooperation and Integration (2016-2020). Manila.  
11 ADB. 2019. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 6: Strengthening Governance and Institutional Capacity, 
2019–2024. Manila. Manila. 
12 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
13 The APTFF 2021 is tentatively scheduled to be held in Singapore in October 2021. This is based on the 
assumption of a physical event, although the TA does not rule out the possibility of a virtual event, depending on 
the pandemic situation. The organizers will monitor the situation and coordinate to determine the most desirable 
course of action given the circumstances.

4 
 
11.  Output  3:  Research  and  assessment  on  developments  in  trade  facilitation 
promoted and disseminated. The TA will conduct five background studies related to post-
COVID-19 trade recovery and the long-term trade facilitation agenda for sustainable trade 
facilitation, focusing on forward-looking trade facilitation research topics with high impacts on 
inclusiveness.  Suggested  research  areas  include  (i)  strengthening  digital  trade  and  trade 
facilitation, (ii) investigating the role of trade facilitation during crises in vulnerable sectors, (iii) 
securing more resilient supply chains, (iv) strengthening support for access to trade finance 
using emerging technology, and (v) adopting an integrated approach for trade and transport 
facilitation. The possible research areas and methodologies will be further discussed internally 
within ADB, particularly with regional departments, to ensure they are timely and relevant to 
ADB operations. As part of the background studies, ADB and ESCAP will jointly produce new 
editions of the Asia-Pacific Trade Facilitation Report for dissemination during the APTFFs. Key 
research findings will also be shared with other ADB departments and disseminated through the 
subregional workshops and other relevant ADB events.  
  
12.  Knowledge  products  will  comprise  mostly  digital  publications.  Printed  external 
publications will be printed for targeted government officials and requestors on demand. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, of which $375,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Fund (TASF 6) and $375,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by TASF-other sources. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA. The Regional Cooperation and Integration Division of the 
Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department will select, supervise, and evaluate 
consultants; organize workshops; and provide staff to act as resource persons in the workshops. 
Implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for 
Support for Forward-Looking Trade Facilitation Measures in Asia and the Pacific, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.
